ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: I did learn to think outside of the francophone literature box and into the anglophone literature--something I do not often have practice doing.

This course introduced me to the fascinating history of the concept of the 'creole' across the Francophone Caribbean and beyond. By examining historical documents as well as literary and theoretical texts, I was able to think diachronically about the creole as a fascinating nexus of racial and linguistic anxieties in the Caribbean.
I was exposed to literature from a wide variety of traditions (Caribbean, French, English, American) and, by exploring the term creole, learned different ways in which to approach these works.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: The readings were comprehensive, varied and interesting. I enjoyed being tasked with an in-class presentation, and listening to the presentations given by my peers. Professor Miller is an invaluable source of knowledge on the subject of the course, as well as a respectful facilitator of discussion.

The strength and weakness of this course was the same: it covered a broad selection of literature from the 1700s to the twentieth century. All the readings were great, and I think that they did fit together. Yet at times it felt scattered. And since creole is such a nebulous, historically-contingent term, it was not always clear what the connection between the different readings was and where the class was going.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: I would certainly recommend this course to any graduate student interested in the history of race and language, as well as ideas/theories of racial hybridity, in the Francophone Caribbean and beyond.
